00040 /**
00041  * @file
00042  *
00043  * "cvmx-usb.h" defines a set of low level USB functions to help
00044  * developers create Octeon USB drivers for various operating
00045  * systems. These functions provide a generic API to the Octeon
00046  * USB blocks, hiding the internal hardware specific
00047  * operations.
00048  *
00049  * At a high level the device driver needs to:
00050  *
00051  * -# Call cvmx_usb_get_num_ports() to get the number of
00052  *  supported ports.
00053  * -# Call cvmx_usb_initialize() for each Octeon USB port.
00054  * -# Enable the port using cvmx_usb_enable().
00055  * -# Either periodically, or in an interrupt handler, call
00056  *  cvmx_usb_poll() to service USB events.
00057  * -# Manage pipes using cvmx_usb_open_pipe() and
00058  *  cvmx_usb_close_pipe().
00059  * -# Manage transfers using cvmx_usb_submit_*() and
00060  *  cvmx_usb_cancel*().
00061  * -# Shutdown USB on unload using cvmx_usb_shutdown().
00062  *
00063  * To monitor USB status changes, the device driver must use
00064  * cvmx_usb_register_callback() to register for events that it
00065  * is interested in. Below are a few hints on successfully
00066  * implementing a driver on top of this API.
00067  *
00068  * <h2>Initialization</h2>
00069  *
00070  * When a driver is first loaded, it is normally not necessary
00071  * to bring up the USB port completely. Most operating systems
00072  * expect to initialize and enable the port in two independent
00073  * steps. Normally an operating system will probe hardware,
00074  * initialize anything found, and then enable the hardware.
00075  *
00076  * In the probe phase you should:
00077  * -# Use cvmx_usb_get_num_ports() to determine the number of
00078  *  USB port to be supported.
00079  * -# Allocate space for a cvmx_usb_state_t structure for each
00080  *  port.
00081  * -# Tell the operating system about each port
00082  *
00083  * In the initialization phase you should:
00084  * -# Use cvmx_usb_initialize() on each port.
00085  * -# Do not call cvmx_usb_enable(). This leaves the USB port in
00086  *  the disabled state until the operating system is ready.
00087  *
00088  * Finally, in the enable phase you should:
00089  * -# Call cvmx_usb_enable() on the appropriate port.
00090  * -# Note that some operating system use a RESET instead of an
00091  *  enable call. To implement RESET, you should call
00092  *  cvmx_usb_disable() followed by cvmx_usb_enable().
00093  *
00094  * <h2>Locking</h2>
00095  *
00096  * All of the functions in the cvmx-usb API assume exclusive
00097  * access to the USB hardware and internal data structures. This
00098  * means that the driver must provide locking as necessary.
00099  *
00100  * In the single CPU state it is normally enough to disable
00101  * interrupts before every call to cvmx_usb*() and enable them
00102  * again after the call is complete. Keep in mind that it is
00103  * very common for the callback handlers to make additional
00104  * calls into cvmx-usb, so the disable/enable must be protected
00105  * against recursion. As an example, the Linux kernel
00106  * local_irq_save() and local_irq_restore() are perfect for this
00107  * in the non SMP case.
00108  *
00109  * In the SMP case, locking is more complicated. For SMP you not
00110  * only need to disable interrupts on the local core, but also
00111  * take a lock to make sure that another core cannot call
00112  * cvmx-usb.
00113  *
00114  * <h2>Port callback</h2>
00115  *
00116  * The port callback prototype needs to look as follows:
00117  *
00118  * void port_callback(cvmx_usb_state_t *usb,
00119  *                    cvmx_usb_callback_t reason,
00120  *                    cvmx_usb_complete_t status,
00121  *                    int pipe_handle,
00122  *                    int submit_handle,
00123  *                    int bytes_transferred,
00124  *                    void *user_data);
00125  * - @b usb is the cvmx_usb_state_t for the port.
00126  * - @b reason will always be
00127  *   CVMX_USB_CALLBACK_PORT_CHANGED.
00128  * - @b status will always be CVMX_USB_COMPLETE_SUCCESS.
00129  * - @b pipe_handle will always be -1.
00130  * - @b submit_handle will always be -1.
00131  * - @b bytes_transferred will always be 0.
00132  * - @b user_data is the void pointer originally passed along
00133  *   with the callback. Use this for any state information you
00134  *   need.
00135  *
00136  * The port callback will be called whenever the user plugs /
00137  * unplugs a device from the port. It will not be called when a
00138  * device is plugged / unplugged from a hub connected to the
00139  * root port. Normally all the callback needs to do is tell the
00140  * operating system to poll the root hub for status. Under
00141  * Linux, this is performed by calling usb_hcd_poll_rh_status().
00142  * In the Linux driver we use @b user_data. to pass around the
00143  * Linux "hcd" structure. Once the port callback completes,
00144  * Linux automatically calls octeon_usb_hub_status_data() which
00145  * uses cvmx_usb_get_status() to determine the root port status.
00146  *
00147  * <h2>Complete callback</h2>
00148  *
00149  * The completion callback prototype needs to look as follows:
00150  *
00151  * void complete_callback(cvmx_usb_state_t *usb,
00152  *                        cvmx_usb_callback_t reason,
00153  *                        cvmx_usb_complete_t status,
00154  *                        int pipe_handle,
00155  *                        int submit_handle,
00156  *                        int bytes_transferred,
00157  *                        void *user_data);
00158  * - @b usb is the cvmx_usb_state_t for the port.
00159  * - @b reason will always be
00160  *   CVMX_USB_CALLBACK_TRANSFER_COMPLETE.
00161  * - @b status will be one of the cvmx_usb_complete_t
00162  *   enumerations.
00163  * - @b pipe_handle is the handle to the pipe the transaction
00164  *   was originally submitted on.
00165  * - @b submit_handle is the handle returned by the original
00166  *   cvmx_usb_submit_* call.
00167  * - @b bytes_transferred is the number of bytes successfully
00168  *   transferred in the transaction. This will be zero on most
00169  *   error conditions.
00170  * - @b user_data is the void pointer originally passed along
00171  *   with the callback. Use this for any state information you
00172  *   need. For example, the Linux "urb" is stored in here in the
00173  *   Linux driver.
00174  *
00175  * In general your callback handler should use @b status and @b
00176  * bytes_transferred to tell the operating system the how the
00177  * transaction completed. Normally the pipe is not changed in
00178  * this callback.
00179  *
00180  * <h2>Canceling transactions</h2>
00181  *
00182  * When a transaction is cancelled using cvmx_usb_cancel*(), the
00183  * actual length of time until the complete callback is called
00184  * can vary greatly. It may be called before cvmx_usb_cancel*()
00185  * returns, or it may be called a number of usb frames in the
00186  * future once the hardware frees the transaction. In either of
00187  * these cases, the complete handler will receive
00188  * CVMX_USB_COMPLETE_CANCEL.
00189  *
00190  * <h2>Handling pipes</h2>
00191  *
00192  * USB "pipes" is a software construct created by this API to
00193  * enable the ordering of usb transactions to a device endpoint.
00194  * Octeon's underlying hardware doesn't have any concept
00195  * equivalent to "pipes". The hardware instead has eight
00196  * channels that can be used simultaneously to have up to eight
00197  * transaction in process at the same time. In order to maintain
00198  * ordering in a pipe, the transactions for a pipe will only be
00199  * active in one hardware channel at a time. From an API user's
00200  * perspective, this doesn't matter but it can be helpful to
00201  * keep this in mind when you are probing hardware while
00202  * debugging.
00203  *
00204  * Also keep in mind that usb transactions contain state
00205  * information about the previous transaction to the same
00206  * endpoint. Each transaction has a PID toggle that changes 0/1
00207  * between each sub packet. This is maintained in the pipe data
00208  * structures. For this reason, you generally cannot create and
00209  * destroy a pipe for every transaction. A sequence of
00210  * transaction to the same endpoint must use the same pipe.
00211  *
00212  * <h2>Root Hub</h2>
00213  *
00214  * Some operating systems view the usb root port as a normal usb
00215  * hub. These systems attempt to control the root hub with
00216  * messages similar to the usb 2.0 spec for hub control and
00217  * status. For these systems it may be necessary to write
00218  * function to decode standard usb control messages into
00219  * equivalent cvmx-usb API calls. As an example, the following
00220  * code is used under Linux for some of the basic hub control
00221  * messages.
00222  *
00223  * @code
00224  * static int octeon_usb_hub_control(struct usb_hcd *hcd, u16 typeReq, u16 wValue, u16 wIndex, char *buf, u16 wLength)
00225  * {
00226  *     cvmx_usb_state_t *usb = (cvmx_usb_state_t *)hcd->hcd_priv;
00227  *     cvmx_usb_port_status_t usb_port_status;
00228  *     int port_status;
00229  *     struct usb_hub_descriptor *desc;
00230  *     unsigned long flags;
00231  *
00232  *     switch (typeReq)
00233  *     {
00234  *         case ClearHubFeature:
00235  *             DEBUG_ROOT_HUB("OcteonUSB: ClearHubFeature\n");
00236  *             switch (wValue)
00237  *             {
00238  *                 case C_HUB_LOCAL_POWER:
00239  *                 case C_HUB_OVER_CURRENT:
00240  *                     // Nothing required here
00241  *                     break;
00242  *                 default:
00243  *                     return -EINVAL;
00244  *             }
00245  *             break;
00246  *         case ClearPortFeature:
00247  *             DEBUG_ROOT_HUB("OcteonUSB: ClearPortFeature");
00248  *             if (wIndex != 1)
00249  *             {
00250  *                 DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" INVALID\n");
00251  *                 return -EINVAL;
00252  *             }
00253  *
00254  *             switch (wValue)
00255  *             {
00256  *                 case USB_PORT_FEAT_ENABLE:
00257  *                     DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" ENABLE");
00258  *                     local_irq_save(flags);
00259  *                     cvmx_usb_disable(usb);
00260  *                     local_irq_restore(flags);
00261  *                     break;
00262  *                 case USB_PORT_FEAT_SUSPEND:
00263  *                     DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" SUSPEND");
00264  *                     // Not supported on Octeon
00265  *                     break;
00266  *                 case USB_PORT_FEAT_POWER:
00267  *                     DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" POWER");
00268  *                     // Not supported on Octeon
00269  *                     break;
00270  *                 case USB_PORT_FEAT_INDICATOR:
00271  *                     DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" INDICATOR");
00272  *                     // Port inidicator not supported
00273  *                     break;
00274  *                 case USB_PORT_FEAT_C_CONNECTION:
00275  *                     DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" C_CONNECTION");
00276  *                     // Clears drivers internal connect status change flag
00277  *                     cvmx_usb_set_status(usb, cvmx_usb_get_status(usb));
00278  *                     break;
00279  *                 case USB_PORT_FEAT_C_RESET:
00280  *                     DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" C_RESET");
00281  *                     // Clears the driver's internal Port Reset Change flag
00282  *                     cvmx_usb_set_status(usb, cvmx_usb_get_status(usb));
00283  *                     break;
00284  *                 case USB_PORT_FEAT_C_ENABLE:
00285  *                     DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" C_ENABLE");
00286  *                     // Clears the driver's internal Port Enable/Disable Change flag
00287  *                     cvmx_usb_set_status(usb, cvmx_usb_get_status(usb));
00288  *                     break;
00289  *                 case USB_PORT_FEAT_C_SUSPEND:
00290  *                     DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" C_SUSPEND");
00291  *                     // Clears the driver's internal Port Suspend Change flag,
00292  *                         which is set when resume signaling on the host port is
00293  *                         complete
00294  *                     break;
00295  *                 case USB_PORT_FEAT_C_OVER_CURRENT:
00296  *                     DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" C_OVER_CURRENT");
00297  *                     // Clears the driver's overcurrent Change flag
00298  *                     cvmx_usb_set_status(usb, cvmx_usb_get_status(usb));
00299  *                     break;
00300  *                 default:
00301  *                     DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" UNKNOWN\n");
00302  *                     return -EINVAL;
00303  *             }
00304  *             DEBUG_ROOT_HUB("\n");
00305  *             break;
00306  *         case GetHubDescriptor:
00307  *             DEBUG_ROOT_HUB("OcteonUSB: GetHubDescriptor\n");
00308  *             desc = (struct usb_hub_descriptor *)buf;
00309  *             desc->bDescLength = 9;
00310  *             desc->bDescriptorType = 0x29;
00311  *             desc->bNbrPorts = 1;
00312  *             desc->wHubCharacteristics = 0x08;
00313  *             desc->bPwrOn2PwrGood = 1;
00314  *             desc->bHubContrCurrent = 0;
00315  *             desc->bitmap[0] = 0;
00316  *             desc->bitmap[1] = 0xff;
00317  *             break;
00318  *         case GetHubStatus:
00319  *             DEBUG_ROOT_HUB("OcteonUSB: GetHubStatus\n");
00320  *             *(__le32 *)buf = 0;
00321  *             break;
00322  *         case GetPortStatus:
00323  *             DEBUG_ROOT_HUB("OcteonUSB: GetPortStatus");
00324  *             if (wIndex != 1)
00325  *             {
00326  *                 DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" INVALID\n");
00327  *                 return -EINVAL;
00328  *             }
00329  *
00330  *             usb_port_status = cvmx_usb_get_status(usb);
00331  *             port_status = 0;
00332  *
00333  *             if (usb_port_status.connect_change)
00334  *             {
00335  *                 port_status |= (1 << USB_PORT_FEAT_C_CONNECTION);
00336  *                 DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" C_CONNECTION");
00337  *             }
00338  *
00339  *             if (usb_port_status.port_enabled)
00340  *             {
00341  *                 port_status |= (1 << USB_PORT_FEAT_C_ENABLE);
00342  *                 DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" C_ENABLE");
00343  *             }
00344  *
00345  *             if (usb_port_status.connected)
00346  *             {
00347  *                 port_status |= (1 << USB_PORT_FEAT_CONNECTION);
00348  *                 DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" CONNECTION");
00349  *             }
00350  *
00351  *             if (usb_port_status.port_enabled)
00352  *             {
00353  *                 port_status |= (1 << USB_PORT_FEAT_ENABLE);
00354  *                 DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" ENABLE");
00355  *             }
00356  *
00357  *             if (usb_port_status.port_over_current)
00358  *             {
00359  *                 port_status |= (1 << USB_PORT_FEAT_OVER_CURRENT);
00360  *                 DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" OVER_CURRENT");
00361  *             }
00362  *
00363  *             if (usb_port_status.port_powered)
00364  *             {
00365  *                 port_status |= (1 << USB_PORT_FEAT_POWER);
00366  *                 DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" POWER");
00367  *             }
00368  *
00369  *             if (usb_port_status.port_speed == CVMX_USB_SPEED_HIGH)
00370  *             {
00371  *                 port_status |= (1 << USB_PORT_FEAT_HIGHSPEED);
00372  *                 DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" HIGHSPEED");
00373  *             }
00374  *             else if (usb_port_status.port_speed == CVMX_USB_SPEED_LOW)
00375  *             {
00376  *                 port_status |= (1 << USB_PORT_FEAT_LOWSPEED);
00377  *                 DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" LOWSPEED");
00378  *             }
00379  *
00380  *             *((__le32 *)buf) = cpu_to_le32(port_status);
00381  *             DEBUG_ROOT_HUB("\n");
00382  *             break;
00383  *         case SetHubFeature:
00384  *             DEBUG_ROOT_HUB("OcteonUSB: SetHubFeature\n");
00385  *             // No HUB features supported
00386  *             break;
00387  *         case SetPortFeature:
00388  *             DEBUG_ROOT_HUB("OcteonUSB: SetPortFeature");
00389  *             if (wIndex != 1)
00390  *             {
00391  *                 DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" INVALID\n");
00392  *                 return -EINVAL;
00393  *             }
00394  *
00395  *             switch (wValue)
00396  *             {
00397  *                 case USB_PORT_FEAT_SUSPEND:
00398  *                     DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" SUSPEND\n");
00399  *                     return -EINVAL;
00400  *                 case USB_PORT_FEAT_POWER:
00401  *                     DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" POWER\n");
00402  *                     return -EINVAL;
00403  *                 case USB_PORT_FEAT_RESET:
00404  *                     DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" RESET\n");
00405  *                     local_irq_save(flags);
00406  *                     cvmx_usb_disable(usb);
00407  *                     if (cvmx_usb_enable(usb))
00408  *                         DEBUG_ERROR("Failed to enable the port\n");
00409  *                     local_irq_restore(flags);
00410  *                     return 0;
00411  *                 case USB_PORT_FEAT_INDICATOR:
00412  *                     DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" INDICATOR\n");
00413  *                     // Not supported
00414  *                     break;
00415  *                 default:
00416  *                     DEBUG_ROOT_HUB(" UNKNOWN\n");
00417  *                     return -EINVAL;
00418  *             }
00419  *             break;
00420  *         default:
00421  *             DEBUG_ROOT_HUB("OcteonUSB: Unknown root hub request\n");
00422  *             return -EINVAL;
00423  *     }
00424  *     return 0;
00425  * }
00426  * @endcode
00427  *
00428  * <h2>Interrupts</h2>
00429  *
00430  * If you plan on using usb interrupts, cvmx_usb_poll() must be
00431  * called on every usb interrupt. It will read the usb state,
00432  * call any needed callbacks, and schedule transactions as
00433  * needed. Your device driver needs only to hookup an interrupt
00434  * handler and call cvmx_usb_poll(). Octeon's usb port 0 causes
00435  * CIU bit CIU_INT*_SUM0[USB] to be set (bit 56). For port 1,
00436  * CIU bit CIU_INT_SUM1[USB1] is set (bit 17). How these bits
00437  * are turned into interrupt numbers is operating system
00438  * specific. For Linux, there are the convenient defines
00439  * OCTEON_IRQ_USB0 and OCTEON_IRQ_USB1 for the IRQ numbers.
00440  *
00441  * If you aren't using interrupts, simple call cvmx_usb_poll()
00442  * in your main processing loop.
00443  *
00444  * <hr>$Revision: 32636 $<hr>
00445  */
00446 
00447 #ifndef __CVMX_USB_H__
00448 #define __CVMX_USB_H__
00449 
00450 #ifdef  __cplusplus
00451 /* *INDENT-OFF* */
00452 extern "C" {
00453 /* *INDENT-ON* */
00454 #endif
00455 
00456 /**
00457  * Enumerations representing the status of function calls.
00458  */
00459 typedef enum {
00460     CVMX_USB_SUCCESS = 0,
00461                     /**< There were no errors */
00462     CVMX_USB_INVALID_PARAM = -1,
00463                     /**< A parameter to the function was invalid */
00464     CVMX_USB_NO_MEMORY = -2,
00465                     /**< Insufficient resources were available for the request */
00466     CVMX_USB_BUSY = -3,     /**< The resource is busy and cannot service the request */
00467     CVMX_USB_TIMEOUT = -4,
00468                     /**< Waiting for an action timed out */
00469     CVMX_USB_INCORRECT_MODE = -5,
00470                     /**< The function call doesn't work in the current USB
00471                                          mode. This happens when host only functions are
00472                                          called in device mode or vice versa */
00473 } cvmx_usb_status_t;
00474 
00475 /**
00476  * Enumerations representing the possible USB device speeds
00477  */
00478 typedef enum {
00479     CVMX_USB_SPEED_HIGH = 0,
00480                     /**< Device is operation at 480Mbps */
00481     CVMX_USB_SPEED_FULL = 1,
00482                     /**< Device is operation at 12Mbps */
00483     CVMX_USB_SPEED_LOW = 2,
00484                     /**< Device is operation at 1.5Mbps */
00485 } cvmx_usb_speed_t;
00486 
00487 /**
00488  * Enumeration representing the possible USB transfer types.
00489  */
00490 typedef enum {
00491     CVMX_USB_TRANSFER_CONTROL = 0,
00492                     /**< USB transfer type control for hub and status transfers */
00493     CVMX_USB_TRANSFER_ISOCHRONOUS = 1,
00494                     /**< USB transfer type isochronous for low priority periodic transfers */
00495     CVMX_USB_TRANSFER_BULK = 2,
00496                     /**< USB transfer type bulk for large low priority transfers */
00497     CVMX_USB_TRANSFER_INTERRUPT = 3,
00498                     /**< USB transfer type interrupt for high priority periodic transfers */
00499 } cvmx_usb_transfer_t;
00500 
00501 /**
00502  * Enumeration of the transfer directions
00503  */
00504 typedef enum {
00505     CVMX_USB_DIRECTION_OUT,
00506                     /**< Data is transferring from Octeon to the device/host */
00507     CVMX_USB_DIRECTION_IN,
00508                     /**< Data is transferring from the device/host to Octeon */
00509 } cvmx_usb_direction_t;
00510 
00511 /**
00512  * Enumeration of all possible status codes passed to callback
00513  * functions.
00514  */
00515 typedef enum {
00516     CVMX_USB_COMPLETE_SUCCESS,
00517                     /**< The transaction / operation finished without any errors */
00518     CVMX_USB_COMPLETE_SHORT,
00519                     /**< This is currently not implemented */
00520     CVMX_USB_COMPLETE_CANCEL,
00521                     /**< The transaction was canceled while in flight by a user call to cvmx_usb_cancel* */
00522     CVMX_USB_COMPLETE_ERROR,
00523                     /**< The transaction aborted with an unexpected error status */
00524     CVMX_USB_COMPLETE_STALL,
00525                     /**< The transaction received a USB STALL response from the device */
00526     CVMX_USB_COMPLETE_XACTERR,
00527                     /**< The transaction failed with an error from the device even after a number of retries */
00528     CVMX_USB_COMPLETE_DATATGLERR,
00529                     /**< The transaction failed with a data toggle error even after a number of retries */
00530     CVMX_USB_COMPLETE_BABBLEERR,
00531                     /**< The transaction failed with a babble error */
00532     CVMX_USB_COMPLETE_FRAMEERR,
00533                     /**< The transaction failed with a frame error even after a number of retries */
00534 } cvmx_usb_complete_t;
00535 
00536 /**
00537  * Structure returned containing the USB port status information.
00538  */
00539 typedef struct {
00540     uint32_t reserved:25;
00541     uint32_t port_enabled:1;
00542                      /**< 1 = Usb port is enabled, 0 = disabled */
00543     uint32_t port_over_current:1;
00544                      /**< 1 = Over current detected, 0 = Over current not detected. Octeon doesn't support over current detection */
00545     uint32_t port_powered:1;
00546                      /**< 1 = Port power is being supplied to the device, 0 = power is off. Octeon doesn't support turning port power off */
00547     cvmx_usb_speed_t port_speed:2;
00548                      /**< Current port speed */
00549     uint32_t connected:1;        /**< 1 = A device is connected to the port, 0 = No device is connected */
00550     uint32_t connect_change:1;
00551                      /**< 1 = Device connected state changed since the last set status call */
00552 } cvmx_usb_port_status_t;
00553 
00554 /**
00555  * This is the structure of a Control packet header
00556  */
00557 typedef union {
00558     uint64_t u64;
00559     struct {
00560         uint64_t request_type:8;
00561                       /**< Bit 7 tells the direction: 1=IN, 0=OUT */
00562         uint64_t request:8;
00563                       /**< The standard usb request to make */
00564         uint64_t value:16;
00565                       /**< Value parameter for the request in little endian format */
00566         uint64_t index:16;
00567                       /**< Index for the request in little endian format */
00568         uint64_t length:16;
00569                       /**< Length of the data associated with this request in little endian format */
00570     } s;
00571 } cvmx_usb_control_header_t;
00572 
00573 /**
00574  * Descriptor for Isochronous packets
00575  */
00576 typedef struct {
00577     int offset;         /**< This is the offset in bytes into the main buffer where this data is stored */
00578     int length;         /**< This is the length in bytes of the data */
00579     cvmx_usb_complete_t status;
00580                     /**< This is the status of this individual packet transfer */
00581 } cvmx_usb_iso_packet_t;
00582 
00583 /**
00584  * Possible callback reasons for the USB API.
00585  */
00586 typedef enum {
00587     CVMX_USB_CALLBACK_TRANSFER_COMPLETE,
00588                     /**< A callback of this type is called when a submitted transfer
00589                                         completes. The completion callback will be called even if the
00590                                         transfer fails or is canceled. The status parameter will
00591                                         contain details of why he callback was called. */
00592     CVMX_USB_CALLBACK_PORT_CHANGED,
00593                     /**< The status of the port changed. For example, someone may have
00594                                         plugged a device in. The status parameter contains
00595                                         CVMX_USB_COMPLETE_SUCCESS. Use cvmx_usb_get_status() to get
00596                                         the new port status. */
00597     __CVMX_USB_CALLBACK_END
00598                     /**< Do not use. Used internally for array bounds */
00599 } cvmx_usb_callback_t;
00600 
00601 /**
00602  * USB state internal data. The contents of this structure
00603  * may change in future SDKs. No data in it should be referenced
00604  * by user's of this API.
00605  */
00606 typedef struct {
00607     char data[65536];
00608 } cvmx_usb_state_t;
00609 
00610 /**
00611  * USB callback functions are always of the following type.
00612  * The parameters are as follows:
00613  *      - state = USB device state populated by
00614  *        cvmx_usb_initialize().
00615  *      - reason = The cvmx_usb_callback_t used to register
00616  *        the callback.
00617  *      - status = The cvmx_usb_complete_t representing the
00618  *        status code of a transaction.
00619  *      - pipe_handle = The Pipe that caused this callback, or
00620  *        -1 if this callback wasn't associated with a pipe.
00621  *      - submit_handle = Transfer submit handle causing this
00622  *        callback, or -1 if this callback wasn't associated
00623  *        with a transfer.
00624  *      - Actual number of bytes transfer.
00625  *      - user_data = The user pointer supplied to the
00626  *        function cvmx_usb_submit() or
00627  *        cvmx_usb_register_callback() */
00628 typedef void (*cvmx_usb_callback_func_t) (cvmx_usb_state_t * state,
00629                       cvmx_usb_callback_t reason, cvmx_usb_complete_t status, int pipe_handle, int submit_handle, int bytes_transferred, void *user_data);
00630 
00631 /**
00632  * Flags to pass the initialization function.
00633  */
00634 typedef enum {
00635     CVMX_USB_INITIALIZE_FLAGS_CLOCK_XO_XI = 1 << 0,
00636                             /**< The USB port uses a 12MHz crystal as clock source
00637                                                             at USB_XO and USB_XI. */
00638     CVMX_USB_INITIALIZE_FLAGS_CLOCK_XO_GND = 1 << 1,
00639                             /**< The USB port uses 12/24/48MHz 2.5V board clock
00640                                                             source at USB_XO. USB_XI should be tied to GND.*/
00641     CVMX_USB_INITIALIZE_FLAGS_CLOCK_AUTO = 0,
00642                             /**< Automatically determine clock type based on function
00643                                                              in cvmx-helper-board.c. */
00644     CVMX_USB_INITIALIZE_FLAGS_CLOCK_MHZ_MASK = 3 << 3,
00645                                 /**< Mask for clock speed field */
00646     CVMX_USB_INITIALIZE_FLAGS_CLOCK_12MHZ = 1 << 3,
00647                             /**< Speed of reference clock or crystal */
00648     CVMX_USB_INITIALIZE_FLAGS_CLOCK_24MHZ = 2 << 3,
00649                             /**< Speed of reference clock */
00650     CVMX_USB_INITIALIZE_FLAGS_CLOCK_48MHZ = 3 << 3,
00651                             /**< Speed of reference clock */
00652     /* Bits 3-4 used to encode the clock frequency */
00653     CVMX_USB_INITIALIZE_FLAGS_NO_DMA = 1 << 5,
00654                             /**< Disable DMA and used polled IO for data transfer use for the USB  */
00655     CVMX_USB_INITIALIZE_FLAGS_DEBUG_TRANSFERS = 1 << 16,
00656                             /**< Enable extra console output for debugging USB transfers */
00657     CVMX_USB_INITIALIZE_FLAGS_DEBUG_CALLBACKS = 1 << 17,
00658                             /**< Enable extra console output for debugging USB callbacks */
00659     CVMX_USB_INITIALIZE_FLAGS_DEBUG_INFO = 1 << 18,
00660                             /**< Enable extra console output for USB informational data */
00661     CVMX_USB_INITIALIZE_FLAGS_DEBUG_CALLS = 1 << 19,
00662                             /**< Enable extra console output for every function call */
00663     CVMX_USB_INITIALIZE_FLAGS_DEBUG_CSRS = 1 << 20,
00664                             /**< Enable extra console output for every CSR access */
00665     CVMX_USB_INITIALIZE_FLAGS_DEBUG_ALL = ((CVMX_USB_INITIALIZE_FLAGS_DEBUG_CSRS << 1) - 1) - (CVMX_USB_INITIALIZE_FLAGS_DEBUG_TRANSFERS - 1),
00666 } cvmx_usb_initialize_flags_t;
00667 
00668 /**
00669  * Flags for passing when a pipe is created. Currently no flags
00670  * need to be passed.
00671  */
00672 typedef enum {
00673     CVMX_USB_PIPE_FLAGS_DEBUG_TRANSFERS = 1 << 15,
00674                         /**< Used to display CVMX_USB_INITIALIZE_FLAGS_DEBUG_TRANSFERS for a specific pipe only */
00675     __CVMX_USB_PIPE_FLAGS_OPEN = 1 << 16,
00676                         /**< Used internally to determine if a pipe is open. Do not use */
00677     __CVMX_USB_PIPE_FLAGS_SCHEDULED = 1 << 17,
00678                         /**< Used internally to determine if a pipe is actively using hardware. Do not use */
00679     __CVMX_USB_PIPE_FLAGS_NEED_PING = 1 << 18,
00680                         /**< Used internally to determine if a high speed pipe is in the ping state. Do not use */
00681 } cvmx_usb_pipe_flags_t;
00682 
00683 /**
00684  * Return the number of USB ports supported by this Octeon
00685  * chip. If the chip doesn't support USB, or is not supported
00686  * by this API, a zero will be returned. Most Octeon chips
00687  * support one usb port, but some support two ports.
00688  * cvmx_usb_initialize() must be called on independent
00689  * cvmx_usb_state_t structures.
00690  *
00691  * @return Number of port, zero if usb isn't supported
00692  */
00693 extern int cvmx_usb_get_num_ports(void);
00694 
00695 /**
00696  * Initialize a USB port for use. This must be called before any
00697  * other access to the Octeon USB port is made. The port starts
00698  * off in the disabled state.
00699  *
00700  * @param state  Pointer to an empty cvmx_usb_state_t structure
00701  *               that will be populated by the initialize call.
00702  *               This structure is then passed to all other USB
00703  *               functions.
00704  * @param usb_port_number
00705  *               Which Octeon USB port to initialize.
00706  * @param flags  Flags to control hardware initialization. See
00707  *               cvmx_usb_initialize_flags_t for the flag
00708  *               definitions. Some flags are mandatory.
00709  *
00710  * @return CVMX_USB_SUCCESS or a negative error code defined in
00711  *         cvmx_usb_status_t.
00712  */
00713 extern cvmx_usb_status_t cvmx_usb_initialize(cvmx_usb_state_t * state, int usb_port_number, cvmx_usb_initialize_flags_t flags);
00714 
00715 /**
00716  * Shutdown a USB port after a call to cvmx_usb_initialize().
00717  * The port should be disabled with all pipes closed when this
00718  * function is called.
00719  *
00720  * @param state  USB device state populated by
00721  *               cvmx_usb_initialize().
00722  *
00723  * @return CVMX_USB_SUCCESS or a negative error code defined in
00724  *         cvmx_usb_status_t.
00725  */
00726 extern cvmx_usb_status_t cvmx_usb_shutdown(cvmx_usb_state_t * state);
00727 
00728 /**
00729  * Enable a USB port. After this call succeeds, the USB port is
00730  * online and servicing requests.
00731  *
00732  * @param state  USB device state populated by
00733  *               cvmx_usb_initialize().
00734  *
00735  * @return CVMX_USB_SUCCESS or a negative error code defined in
00736  *         cvmx_usb_status_t.
00737  */
00738 extern cvmx_usb_status_t cvmx_usb_enable(cvmx_usb_state_t * state);
00739 
00740 /**
00741  * Disable a USB port. After this call the USB port will not
00742  * generate data transfers and will not generate events.
00743  * Transactions in process will fail and call their
00744  * associated callbacks.
00745  *
00746  * @param state  USB device state populated by
00747  *               cvmx_usb_initialize().
00748  *
00749  * @return CVMX_USB_SUCCESS or a negative error code defined in
00750  *         cvmx_usb_status_t.
00751  */
00752 extern cvmx_usb_status_t cvmx_usb_disable(cvmx_usb_state_t * state);
00753 
00754 /**
00755  * Get the current state of the USB port. Use this call to
00756  * determine if the usb port has anything connected, is enabled,
00757  * or has some sort of error condition. The return value of this
00758  * call has "changed" bits to signal of the value of some fields
00759  * have changed between calls. These "changed" fields are based
00760  * on the last call to cvmx_usb_set_status(). In order to clear
00761  * them, you must update the status through cvmx_usb_set_status().
00762  *
00763  * @param state  USB device state populated by
00764  *               cvmx_usb_initialize().
00765  *
00766  * @return Port status information
00767  */
00768 extern cvmx_usb_port_status_t cvmx_usb_get_status(cvmx_usb_state_t * state);
00769 
00770 /**
00771  * Set the current state of the USB port. The status is used as
00772  * a reference for the "changed" bits returned by
00773  * cvmx_usb_get_status(). Other than serving as a reference, the
00774  * status passed to this function is not used. No fields can be
00775  * changed through this call.
00776  *
00777  * @param state  USB device state populated by
00778  *               cvmx_usb_initialize().
00779  * @param port_status
00780  *               Port status to set, most like returned by cvmx_usb_get_status()
00781  */
00782 extern void cvmx_usb_set_status(cvmx_usb_state_t * state, cvmx_usb_port_status_t port_status);
00783 
00784 /**
00785  * Open a virtual pipe between the host and a USB device. A pipe
00786  * must be opened before data can be transferred between a device
00787  * and Octeon.
00788  *
00789  * @param state      USB device state populated by
00790  *                   cvmx_usb_initialize().
00791  * @param flags      Optional pipe flags defined in
00792  *                   cvmx_usb_pipe_flags_t.
00793  * @param device_addr
00794  *                   USB device address to open the pipe to
00795  *                   (0-127).
00796  * @param endpoint_num
00797  *                   USB endpoint number to open the pipe to
00798  *                   (0-15).
00799  * @param device_speed
00800  *                   The speed of the device the pipe is going
00801  *                   to. This must match the device's speed,
00802  *                   which may be different than the port speed.
00803  * @param max_packet The maximum packet length the device can
00804  *                   transmit/receive (low speed=0-8, full
00805  *                   speed=0-1023, high speed=0-1024). This value
00806  *                   comes from the standard endpoint descriptor
00807  *                   field wMaxPacketSize bits <10:0>.
00808  * @param transfer_type
00809  *                   The type of transfer this pipe is for.
00810  * @param transfer_dir
00811  *                   The direction the pipe is in. This is not
00812  *                   used for control pipes.
00813  * @param interval   For ISOCHRONOUS and INTERRUPT transfers,
00814  *                   this is how often the transfer is scheduled
00815  *                   for. All other transfers should specify
00816  *                   zero. The units are in frames (8000/sec at
00817  *                   high speed, 1000/sec for full speed).
00818  * @param multi_count
00819  *                   For high speed devices, this is the maximum
00820  *                   allowed number of packet per microframe.
00821  *                   Specify zero for non high speed devices. This
00822  *                   value comes from the standard endpoint descriptor
00823  *                   field wMaxPacketSize bits <12:11>.
00824  * @param hub_device_addr
00825  *                   Hub device address this device is connected
00826  *                   to. Devices connected directly to Octeon
00827  *                   use zero. This is only used when the device
00828  *                   is full/low speed behind a high speed hub.
00829  *                   The address will be of the high speed hub,
00830  *                   not and full speed hubs after it.
00831  * @param hub_port   Which port on the hub the device is
00832  *                   connected. Use zero for devices connected
00833  *                   directly to Octeon. Like hub_device_addr,
00834  *                   this is only used for full/low speed
00835  *                   devices behind a high speed hub.
00836  *
00837  * @return A non negative value is a pipe handle. Negative
00838  *         values are failure codes from cvmx_usb_status_t.
00839  */
00840 extern int cvmx_usb_open_pipe(cvmx_usb_state_t * state,
00841                   cvmx_usb_pipe_flags_t flags,
00842                   int device_addr, int endpoint_num,
00843                   cvmx_usb_speed_t device_speed, int max_packet,
00844                   cvmx_usb_transfer_t transfer_type, cvmx_usb_direction_t transfer_dir, int interval, int multi_count, int hub_device_addr, int hub_port);
00845 
00846 /**
00847  * Call to submit a USB Bulk transfer to a pipe.
00848  *
00849  * @param state     USB device state populated by
00850  *                  cvmx_usb_initialize().
00851  * @param pipe_handle
00852  *                  Handle to the pipe for the transfer.
00853  * @param buffer    Physical address of the data buffer in
00854  *                  memory. Note that this is NOT A POINTER, but
00855  *                  the full 64bit physical address of the
00856  *                  buffer. This may be zero if buffer_length is
00857  *                  zero.
00858  * @param buffer_length
00859  *                  Length of buffer in bytes.
00860  * @param callback  Function to call when this transaction
00861  *                  completes. If the return value of this
00862  *                  function isn't an error, then this function
00863  *                  is guaranteed to be called when the
00864  *                  transaction completes. If this parameter is
00865  *                  NULL, then the generic callback registered
00866  *                  through cvmx_usb_register_callback is
00867  *                  called. If both are NULL, then there is no
00868  *                  way to know when a transaction completes.
00869  * @param user_data User supplied data returned when the
00870  *                  callback is called. This is only used if
00871  *                  callback in not NULL.
00872  *
00873  * @return A submitted transaction handle or negative on
00874  *         failure. Negative values are failure codes from
00875  *         cvmx_usb_status_t.
00876  */
00877 extern int cvmx_usb_submit_bulk(cvmx_usb_state_t * state, int pipe_handle, uint64_t buffer, int buffer_length, cvmx_usb_callback_func_t callback, void *user_data);
00878 
00879 /**
00880  * Call to submit a USB Interrupt transfer to a pipe.
00881  *
00882  * @param state     USB device state populated by
00883  *                  cvmx_usb_initialize().
00884  * @param pipe_handle
00885  *                  Handle to the pipe for the transfer.
00886  * @param buffer    Physical address of the data buffer in
00887  *                  memory. Note that this is NOT A POINTER, but
00888  *                  the full 64bit physical address of the
00889  *                  buffer. This may be zero if buffer_length is
00890  *                  zero.
00891  * @param buffer_length
00892  *                  Length of buffer in bytes.
00893  * @param callback  Function to call when this transaction
00894  *                  completes. If the return value of this
00895  *                  function isn't an error, then this function
00896  *                  is guaranteed to be called when the
00897  *                  transaction completes. If this parameter is
00898  *                  NULL, then the generic callback registered
00899  *                  through cvmx_usb_register_callback is
00900  *                  called. If both are NULL, then there is no
00901  *                  way to know when a transaction completes.
00902  * @param user_data User supplied data returned when the
00903  *                  callback is called. This is only used if
00904  *                  callback in not NULL.
00905  *
00906  * @return A submitted transaction handle or negative on
00907  *         failure. Negative values are failure codes from
00908  *         cvmx_usb_status_t.
00909  */
00910 extern int cvmx_usb_submit_interrupt(cvmx_usb_state_t * state, int pipe_handle, uint64_t buffer, int buffer_length, cvmx_usb_callback_func_t callback, void *user_data);
00911 
00912 /**
00913  * Call to submit a USB Control transfer to a pipe.
00914  *
00915  * @param state     USB device state populated by
00916  *                  cvmx_usb_initialize().
00917  * @param pipe_handle
00918  *                  Handle to the pipe for the transfer.
00919  * @param control_header
00920  *                  USB 8 byte control header physical address.
00921  *                  Note that this is NOT A POINTER, but the
00922  *                  full 64bit physical address of the buffer.
00923  * @param buffer    Physical address of the data buffer in
00924  *                  memory. Note that this is NOT A POINTER, but
00925  *                  the full 64bit physical address of the
00926  *                  buffer. This may be zero if buffer_length is
00927  *                  zero.
00928  * @param buffer_length
00929  *                  Length of buffer in bytes.
00930  * @param callback  Function to call when this transaction
00931  *                  completes. If the return value of this
00932  *                  function isn't an error, then this function
00933  *                  is guaranteed to be called when the
00934  *                  transaction completes. If this parameter is
00935  *                  NULL, then the generic callback registered
00936  *                  through cvmx_usb_register_callback is
00937  *                  called. If both are NULL, then there is no
00938  *                  way to know when a transaction completes.
00939  * @param user_data User supplied data returned when the
00940  *                  callback is called. This is only used if
00941  *                  callback in not NULL.
00942  *
00943  * @return A submitted transaction handle or negative on
00944  *         failure. Negative values are failure codes from
00945  *         cvmx_usb_status_t.
00946  */
00947 extern int cvmx_usb_submit_control(cvmx_usb_state_t * state, int pipe_handle,
00948                    uint64_t control_header, uint64_t buffer, int buffer_length, cvmx_usb_callback_func_t callback, void *user_data);
00949 
00950 /**
00951  * Flags to pass the cvmx_usb_submit_isochronous() function.
00952  */
00953 typedef enum {
00954     CVMX_USB_ISOCHRONOUS_FLAGS_ALLOW_SHORT = 1 << 0,
00955                             /**< Do not return an error if a transfer is less than the maximum packet size of the device */
00956     CVMX_USB_ISOCHRONOUS_FLAGS_ASAP = 1 << 1,
00957                             /**< Schedule the transaction as soon as possible */
00958 } cvmx_usb_isochronous_flags_t;
00959 
00960 /**
00961  * Call to submit a USB Isochronous transfer to a pipe.
00962  *
00963  * @param state     USB device state populated by
00964  *                  cvmx_usb_initialize().
00965  * @param pipe_handle
00966  *                  Handle to the pipe for the transfer.
00967  * @param start_frame
00968  *                  Number of frames into the future to schedule
00969  *                  this transaction.
00970  * @param flags     Flags to control the transfer. See
00971  *                  cvmx_usb_isochronous_flags_t for the flag
00972  *                  definitions.
00973  * @param number_packets
00974  *                  Number of sequential packets to transfer.
00975  *                  "packets" is a pointer to an array of this
00976  *                  many packet structures.
00977  * @param packets   Description of each transfer packet as
00978  *                  defined by cvmx_usb_iso_packet_t. The array
00979  *                  pointed to here must stay valid until the
00980  *                  complete callback is called.
00981  * @param buffer    Physical address of the data buffer in
00982  *                  memory. Note that this is NOT A POINTER, but
00983  *                  the full 64bit physical address of the
00984  *                  buffer. This may be zero if buffer_length is
00985  *                  zero.
00986  * @param buffer_length
00987  *                  Length of buffer in bytes.
00988  * @param callback  Function to call when this transaction
00989  *                  completes. If the return value of this
00990  *                  function isn't an error, then this function
00991  *                  is guaranteed to be called when the
00992  *                  transaction completes. If this parameter is
00993  *                  NULL, then the generic callback registered
00994  *                  through cvmx_usb_register_callback is
00995  *                  called. If both are NULL, then there is no
00996  *                  way to know when a transaction completes.
00997  * @param user_data User supplied data returned when the
00998  *                  callback is called. This is only used if
00999  *                  callback in not NULL.
01000  *
01001  * @return A submitted transaction handle or negative on
01002  *         failure. Negative values are failure codes from
01003  *         cvmx_usb_status_t.
01004  */
01005 extern int cvmx_usb_submit_isochronous(cvmx_usb_state_t * state, int pipe_handle,
01006                        int start_frame, int flags,
01007                        int number_packets, cvmx_usb_iso_packet_t packets[], uint64_t buffer, int buffer_length, cvmx_usb_callback_func_t callback, void *user_data);
01008 
01009 /**
01010  * Cancel one outstanding request in a pipe. Canceling a request
01011  * can fail if the transaction has already completed before cancel
01012  * is called. Even after a successful cancel call, it may take
01013  * a frame or two for the cvmx_usb_poll() function to call the
01014  * associated callback.
01015  *
01016  * @param state  USB device state populated by
01017  *               cvmx_usb_initialize().
01018  * @param pipe_handle
01019  *               Pipe handle to cancel requests in.
01020  * @param submit_handle
01021  *               Handle to transaction to cancel, returned by the submit function.
01022  *
01023  * @return CVMX_USB_SUCCESS or a negative error code defined in
01024  *         cvmx_usb_status_t.
01025  */
01026 extern cvmx_usb_status_t cvmx_usb_cancel(cvmx_usb_state_t * state, int pipe_handle, int submit_handle);
01027 
01028 /**
01029  * Cancel all outstanding requests in a pipe. Logically all this
01030  * does is call cvmx_usb_cancel() in a loop.
01031  *
01032  * @param state  USB device state populated by
01033  *               cvmx_usb_initialize().
01034  * @param pipe_handle
01035  *               Pipe handle to cancel requests in.
01036  *
01037  * @return CVMX_USB_SUCCESS or a negative error code defined in
01038  *         cvmx_usb_status_t.
01039  */
01040 extern cvmx_usb_status_t cvmx_usb_cancel_all(cvmx_usb_state_t * state, int pipe_handle);
01041 
01042 /**
01043  * Close a pipe created with cvmx_usb_open_pipe().
01044  *
01045  * @param state  USB device state populated by
01046  *               cvmx_usb_initialize().
01047  * @param pipe_handle
01048  *               Pipe handle to close.
01049  *
01050  * @return CVMX_USB_SUCCESS or a negative error code defined in
01051  *         cvmx_usb_status_t. CVMX_USB_BUSY is returned if the
01052  *         pipe has outstanding transfers.
01053  */
01054 extern cvmx_usb_status_t cvmx_usb_close_pipe(cvmx_usb_state_t * state, int pipe_handle);
01055 
01056 /**
01057  * Register a function to be called when various USB events occur.
01058  *
01059  * @param state     USB device state populated by
01060  *                  cvmx_usb_initialize().
01061  * @param reason    Which event to register for.
01062  * @param callback  Function to call when the event occurs.
01063  * @param user_data User data parameter to the function.
01064  *
01065  * @return CVMX_USB_SUCCESS or a negative error code defined in
01066  *         cvmx_usb_status_t.
01067  */
01068 extern cvmx_usb_status_t cvmx_usb_register_callback(cvmx_usb_state_t * state, cvmx_usb_callback_t reason, cvmx_usb_callback_func_t callback, void *user_data);
01069 
01070 /**
01071  * Get the current USB protocol level frame number. The frame
01072  * number is always in the range of 0-0x7ff.
01073  *
01074  * @param state  USB device state populated by
01075  *               cvmx_usb_initialize().
01076  *
01077  * @return USB frame number
01078  */
01079 extern int cvmx_usb_get_frame_number(cvmx_usb_state_t * state);
01080 
01081 /**
01082  * Poll the USB block for status and call all needed callback
01083  * handlers. This function is meant to be called in the interrupt
01084  * handler for the USB controller. It can also be called
01085  * periodically in a loop for non-interrupt based operation.
01086  *
01087  * @param state  USB device state populated by
01088  *               cvmx_usb_initialize().
01089  *
01090  * @return CVMX_USB_SUCCESS or a negative error code defined in
01091  *         cvmx_usb_status_t.
01092  */
01093 extern cvmx_usb_status_t cvmx_usb_poll(cvmx_usb_state_t * state);
01094 
01095 #ifdef  __cplusplus
01096 /* *INDENT-OFF* */
01097 }
01098 /* *INDENT-ON* */
01099 #endif
01100 #endif /* __CVMX_USB_H__ */
